# _The North Star_ (anti-slavery newspaper)

NorthStarfrontpage.jpg)](/wiki/File:NorthStarfrontpage.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:NorthStarfrontpage.jpg "Enlarge")

June 2, 1848 issue

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/North_Star_Newspaper_February_22%2C_1856.jpeg/170px-
North_Star_Newspaper_February_22%2C_1856.jpeg)](/wiki/File:North_Star_Newspaper_February_22,_1856.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:North_Star_Newspaper_February_22,_1856.jpeg "Enlarge")

February 22, 1856 issue

    _For other newspapers named North Star, see[North Star (disambiguation)#Newspapers](/wiki/North_Star_\(disambiguation\)#Newspapers "North Star \(disambiguation\)")_

_**The North Star**_ was a nineteenth-century anti-slavery newspaper published
from the [Talman Building](/wiki/Talman_Building "Talman Building") in
[Rochester, New York](/wiki/Rochester,_New_York "Rochester, New York") by
abolitionist [Frederick Douglass](/wiki/Frederick_Douglass "Frederick
Douglass").[1] The paper commenced publication on December 3, 1847 and ceased
as _The North Star_ in June 1851 when it merged with [Gerrit
Smith's](/wiki/Gerrit_Smith "Gerrit Smith") _[Liberty Party
Paper](/w/index.php?title=Liberty_Party_Paper&action=edit&redlink=1 "Liberty
Party Paper \(page does not exist\)")_ (based in [Syracuse, New
York](/wiki/Syracuse,_New_York "Syracuse, New York")) to form _Frederick
Douglass ' Paper_.[2] _The North Star '_s slogan was "Right is of no Sex—Truth
is of no Color—God is the Father of us all, and we are all Brethren."[3]

## Inspiration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_North_Star_\(anti-
slavery_newspaper\)&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Inspiration")]

In 1846, Frederick Douglass was first inspired to publish _The North Star_
after subscribing to _[The Liberator](/wiki/The_Liberator_\(newspaper\) "The
Liberator \(newspaper\)")_ , a weekly newspaper published by [William Lloyd
Garrison](/wiki/William_Lloyd_Garrison "William Lloyd Garrison"). The
_Liberator_ was a newspaper established by Garrison and his supporters founded
upon moral principles.[2] The _North Star_ title was a reference to the
directions given to runaway slaves trying to reach the Northern states and
Canada: Follow the North Star.[4] Published weekly, _The North Star_ was four
pages long and sold by subscription at the cost of $2 per year to more than
4,000 readers in the United States, Europe, and the West Indies. The first of
its four pages focused on current events concerning abolitionist issues.[5]

The Garrisonian _Liberator_ was founded upon the notion that the Constitution
was fundamentally pro-slavery and that the Union ought to be dissolved.
Douglass disagreed but supported the [nonviolent](/wiki/Nonviolent
"Nonviolent") approach to the emancipation of slaves by education and moral
suasion.[6] Under the guidance of the abolitionist society, Douglass became
well acquainted with the pursuit of the emancipation of slaves through a New
England religious perspective.[7] Garrison had earlier convinced the
Massachusetts Anti-Slavery Society to hire Douglass as an agent, touring with
Garrison and telling audiences about his experiences in slavery Douglass
worked with another abolitionist, [Martin R. Delany](/wiki/Martin_R._Delany
"Martin R. Delany"), who traveled to lecture, report, and generate
subscriptions to _The North Star_.[4]

Douglass' thoughts toward political inaction changed when he attended the
National Convention of Colored Citizens, an antislavery convention in
[Buffalo, New York](/wiki/Buffalo,_New_York "Buffalo, New York"), in August
1843. One of the many speakers present at the convention was [Henry Highland
Garnet](/wiki/Henry_Highland_Garnet "Henry Highland Garnet"). Formerly a slave
in Maryland, Garnet was a Presbyterian minister who supported violent action
against slaveholders. Garnet's demands of independent action addressed to the
American slaves remained one of the leading issues of change for Douglass.

During a nineteen-month stay in
[Britain](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland") and [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"), several of
Douglass’ supporters bought his freedom and assisted with the purchase of a
[printing press](/wiki/Printing_press "Printing press"). With this assistance
Douglass was determined to begin an [African-American](/wiki/African-American
"African-American") newspaper that would engage the anti-slavery movement
politically. On his return to the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United
States") in March 1847, Douglass shared his ideas of _The North Star_ with his
mentors. Ignoring the advice of the [American Anti-Slavery
Society](/wiki/American_Anti-Slavery_Society "American Anti-Slavery Society"),
Douglass moved to [Rochester, New York](/wiki/Rochester,_New_York "Rochester,
New York") to publish the first edition. When questioned on his decision to
create _The North Star_ , Douglass is said to have responded,

> "I still see before me a life of toil and trials..., but, justice must be
> done, the truth must be told...I will not be silent."[8]

In covering politics in Europe, literature, slavery in the United States, and
culture generally in both _The North Star_ and _[Frederick Douglass'
Paper](/w/index.php?title=Frederick_Douglass%27_Paper&action=edit&redlink=1
"Frederick Douglass' Paper \(page does not exist\)")_, Douglass achieved an
unconstrained independence to write freely on topics from the California Gold
Rush to _Uncle Tom 's Cabin_ to Charles Dickens's _Bleak House._[9]
